title: Daily Evening Bhagavatam Discourse | SB 1.17.19 Part 1 | HH Stoka Krishna Swami | 25-02-2023
speaker: HH Stoka Krishna Swami

segments.key_quote: Om Agyanati Miran Dhasya Gyananjan Shalakaya Chakshuran Militam Yena Tasmai Shri Gurave Namaha
segments.summary: The lecture begins with traditional Vaishnava prayers and mantras, invoking blessings and paying respects to the spiritual master and the Lord.

segments.key_quote: Some of the philosophers who deny all sorts of duality declare that one's own self is responsible for his personal happiness and distress.
segments.summary: The speaker introduces the 19th verse of the 17th chapter of the 1st canto of Srimad Bhagavatam, which discusses different philosophical perspectives on the cause of suffering, setting the stage for a discussion of various philosophical schools.

segments.key_quote: Jaimini analyzes people can perform either sinful activity or pious activity if they perform pious activity they are going to get enjoyment or happiness if they perform sinful activity they are going to get happiness and if they do not they are going to get suffering or pain or some distress this is jaimini's analysis
segments.summary: The speaker delves into the Karma Mimamsa philosophy of Jaimini, explaining that suffering and enjoyment are direct results of one's past actions, both sinful and pious, and that even gods are bound by the laws of karma.

segments.key_quote: even if somebody is a devotee of some supreme god or devotee of some devata or believer of some some higher controller still that controller or controllers or supreme lord has to award the results of one's past activities and those results are awarded in terms of suffering or happiness enjoyment this is karma
segments.summary: The speaker continues explaining Jaimini's Karma Mimamsa philosophy, emphasizing that even devotion to a supreme god or devatas does not override the law of karma, which dictates that everyone must experience the consequences of their actions.

segments.key_quote: So, the Vedic philosophies, five Vedic philosophies other than Vyasadeva's Vedanta Darshana, um Nyaya, Vaisheshika, ah Yoga Sutra of Patanjali, ah Karma Mimamsa and and um and one more Sankhya. So, these five philosophies they have some merit, but they also are defective in some ways.
segments.summary: The speaker introduces Vyasadeva's refutation of Karma Mimamsa and other Vedic philosophies, stating that while they have some merit, they are incomplete compared to Vedanta Darshana, which is based on the parampara system.

segments.key_quote: Bhagavad Gita, it is explained very clearly that the scriptures are originating from the Supreme personality of Godhead, Krishna.
segments.summary: The speaker explains that Vedic knowledge originates from Krishna and was imparted to Brahma, then passed down through the parampara system to Vyasa, who documented it in the Vedic literature.

segments.key_quote: pure devotees or devotees engaged in pure devotional service don't suffer exactly whatever reactions are there in their heart their reactions are nullified by their pure devotional service and who does that Krishna does it because only Krishna has got that power to nullify sinful reactions nobody else can only Krishna can do that.
segments.summary: The speaker concludes by explaining that while Karma Mimamsa is correct to some extent, it is incomplete because it doesn't account for Krishna's role in enforcing and nullifying karma, especially for devotees engaged in pure devotional service.
